element.name: fileset
element.description: The java files or directory to audit. Whatever the filter is, only the files that end with .java will be included for processing. Note that the base directory used for the fileset MUST be the root of the source files otherwise package names deduced from the file path will be incorrect.

element.name: classpath
element.description: Sets the class path (also source path unless one explicitly set). Overrides METAPATH/CLASSPATH environment variables.

element.name: jvmarg
element.description:
Additional optional parameters to pass to the JVM. You can avoid using the <jvmarg> by adding these empty entries to metamata.properties located at ${metamata.home}/bin 
metamata.classpath=
 metamata.sourcepath=

task.name: move
task.description:
Moves a file or directory to a new file or directory. By default, the destination file is overwritten if it already exists. When overwrite is turned off, then files are only moved if the source file is newer than the destination file, or when the destination file does not exist.

Source files and directories are only deleted when the file or directory has been copied to the destination successfully. Filtering also works.

This implementation is based on Arnout Kuiper's initial design document, the following mailing list discussions, and the copyfile/copydir tasks.

attribute.name: encoding
attribute.description: Sets the character encoding

attribute.name: failonerror
attribute.description: If false, note errors to the output but keep going.

attribute.name: file
attribute.required: one of file or at least one nested fileset element
attribute.description: Sets a single source file to copy.

attribute.name: filtering
attribute.description: If true, enables filtering.

attribute.name: flatten
attribute.description: When copying directory trees, the files can be "flattened" into a single directory. If there are multiple files with the same name in the source directory tree, only the first file will be copied into the "flattened" directory, unless the forceoverwrite attribute is true.

attribute.name: includeemptydirs
attribute.description: Used to copy empty directories.

attribute.name: overwrite
attribute.description: Overwrite any existing destination file(s).

attribute.name: preservelastmodified
attribute.description: Give the copied files the same last modified time as the original files.

attribute.name: todir
attribute.description: Sets the destination directory.

attribute.name: tofile
attribute.required: with the file attribute, either tofile or todir can be used. with nested filesets, if the fileset size is greater than 1 or if the only entry in the fileset is a directory or if the file attribute is already specified, only todir is allowed
attribute.description: Sets the destination file.

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description: Used to force listing of all names of copied files.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Adds a set of files to copy.

element.name: filterchain
element.description: Adds a FilterChain.

element.description: Adds a filterset.

element.description: Defines the mapper to map source to destination files.

attribute.description: Set the encoding to translate to/from. If unset, the default encoding for the JVM is used.

attribute.description: Set the extension which converted files should have. If unset, files will not be renamed.

attribute.name: reverse
attribute.description: Flag the conversion to run in the reverse sense, that is Ascii to Native encoding.

task.name: netrexxc
task.description:
Compiles NetRexx source files.

When this task executes, it will recursively scan the srcdir looking for NetRexx source files to compile. This task makes its compile decision based on timestamp.

Before files are compiled they and any other file in the srcdir will be copied to the destdir allowing support files to be located properly in the classpath. The reason for copying the source files before the compile is that NetRexxC has only two destinations for classfiles:

  1. The current directory, and,
  2. The directory the source is in (see sourcedir option)

attribute.name: binary
attribute.description: Set whether literals are treated as binary, rather than NetRexx types

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Set the classpath used for NetRexx compilation

attribute.name: comments
attribute.description: Set whether comments are passed through to the generated java source. Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false

attribute.name: compact
attribute.description: Set whether error messages come out in compact or verbose format. Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false

attribute.name: compile
attribute.description: Set whether the NetRexx compiler should compile the generated java code Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is true. Setting this flag to false, will automatically set the keep flag to true.

attribute.name: console
attribute.description: Set whether or not messages should be displayed on the 'console' Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is true.

attribute.name: crossref
attribute.description: Whether variable cross references are generated

attribute.name: decimal
attribute.description: Set whether decimal arithmetic should be used for the netrexx code. Binary arithmetic is used when this flag is turned off. Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is true.

attribute.name: destdir
attribute.description: Set the destination directory into which the NetRexx source files should be copied and then compiled.

attribute.name: diag
attribute.description: Whether diagnostic information about the compile is generated

attribute.name: explicit
attribute.description: Sets whether variables must be declared explicitly before use. Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: format
attribute.description: Whether the generated Java code is formatted nicely or left to match NetRexx line numbers for call stack debugging

attribute.name: java
attribute.description: Whether the generated Java code is produced Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: keep
attribute.description: Sets whether the generated java source file should be kept after compilation. The generated files will have an extension of .java.keep, not .java Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: logo
attribute.description: Whether the compiler text logo is displayed when compiling

attribute.name: replace
attribute.description: Whether the generated .java file should be replaced when compiling Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: savelog
attribute.description: Sets whether the compiler messages will be written to NetRexxC.log as well as to the console Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: sourcedir
attribute.description: Tells the NetRexx compiler to store the class files in the same directory as the source files. The alternative is the working directory Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is true.

attribute.name: srcdir
attribute.description: Set the source dir to find the source Java files.

attribute.name: strictargs
attribute.description: Tells the NetRexx compiler that method calls always need parentheses, even if no arguments are needed, e.g. aStringVar.getBytes vs. aStringVar.getBytes() Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: strictassign
attribute.description: Tells the NetRexx compile that assignments must match exactly on type

attribute.name: strictcase
attribute.description: Specifies whether the NetRexx compiler should be case sensitive or not

attribute.name: strictimport
attribute.description: Sets whether classes need to be imported explicitly using an import statement. By default the NetRexx compiler will import certain packages automatically Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: strictprops
attribute.description: Sets whether local properties need to be qualified explicitly using this Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: strictsignal
attribute.description: Whether the compiler should force catching of exceptions by explicitly named types

attribute.name: suppressdeprecation
attribute.description: Tells whether we should filter out any deprecation-messages of the compiler out.

attribute.name: suppressexceptionnotsignalled
attribute.description: Whether the task should suppress the "FooException is in SIGNALS list but is not signalled within the method", which is sometimes rather useless. The warning is logged as verbose message, though.

attribute.name: suppressmethodargumentnotused
attribute.description: Whether the task should suppress the "Method argument is not used" in strictargs-Mode, which can not be suppressed by the compiler itself. The warning is logged as verbose message, though.

attribute.name: suppressprivatepropertynotused
attribute.description: Whether the task should suppress the "Private property is defined but not used" in strictargs-Mode, which can be quite annoying while developing. The warning is logged as verbose message, though.

attribute.name: suppressvariablenotused
attribute.description: Whether the task should suppress the "Variable is set but not used" in strictargs-Mode. Be careful with this one! The warning is logged as verbose message, though.

attribute.name: symbols
attribute.description: Sets whether debug symbols should be generated into the class file Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: time
attribute.description: Asks the NetRexx compiler to print compilation times to the console Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: utf8
attribute.description: Tells the NetRexx compiler that the source is in UTF8 Valid true values are "on" or "true". Anything else sets the flag to false. The default value is false.

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description: Whether lots of warnings and error messages should be generated

task.name: p4add
task.description:
Adds specified files to Perforce. Example Usage:
FunctionCommand
Add files using P4USER, P4PORT and P4CLIENT settings specified<P4add
P4view="//projects/foo/main/source/..."
P4User="fbloggs"
P4Port="km01:1666"
P4Client="fbloggsclient">
<fileset basedir="dir" includes="**/*.java">
</p4add>
Add files using P4USER, P4PORT and P4CLIENT settings defined in environment<P4add P4view="//projects/foo/main/source/..." />
<fileset basedir="dir" includes="**/*.java">
</p4add>
Specify the length of command line arguments to pass to each invocation of p4<p4add Commandlength="450">

task.name: p4counter
task.description:
Obtains or sets the value of a counter.

When used in its base form (where only the counter name is provided), the counter value will be printed to the output stream. When the value is provided, the counter will be set to the value provided. When a property name is provided, the property will be filled with the value of the counter. You may not specify to both get and set the value of the counter in the same Task.

The user performing this task must have Perforce "review" permissions as defined by Perforce protections in order for this task to succeed.

Example Usage:
<p4counter name="${p4.counter}" property=${p4.change}"/>

attribute.name: property

attribute.name: user

attribute.name: value

attribute.name: view

task.name: property
task.description:
Sets a property by name, or set of properties (from file or resource) in the project.

Properties are immutable: whoever sets a property first freezes it for the rest of the build; they are most definately not variable.

There are five ways to set properties:

  • By supplying both the name and value attribute.
  • By supplying both the name and refid attribute.
  • By setting the file attribute with the filename of the property file to load. This property file has the format as defined by the file used in the class java.util.Properties.
  • By setting the resource attribute with the resource name of the property file to load. This property file has the format as defined by the file used in the class java.util.Properties.
  • By setting the environment attribute with a prefix to use. Properties will be defined for every environment variable by prefixing the supplied name and a period to the name of the variable.

Although combinations of these ways are possible, only one should be used at a time. Problems might occur with the order in which properties are set, for instance.

The value part of the properties being set, might contain references to other properties. These references are resolved at the time these properties are set. This also holds for properties loaded from a property file.

Properties are case sensitive.

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: The classpath to use when looking up a resource.

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: the classpath to use when looking up a resource, given as reference to a <path> defined elsewhere

attribute.name: environment
attribute.description:
the prefix to use when retrieving environment variables. Thus if you specify environment="myenv" you will be able to access OS-specific environment variables via property names "myenv.PATH" or "myenv.TERM".

Note that if you supply a property name with a final "." it will not be doubled. ie environment="myenv." will still allow access of environment variables through "myenv.PATH" and "myenv.TERM". This functionality is currently only implemented on select platforms. Feel free to send patches to increase the number of platforms this functionality is supported on ;).
Note also that properties are case sensitive, even if the environment variables on your operating system are not, e.g. it will be ${env.Path} not ${env.PATH} on Windows 2000.

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: the filename of a property file to load.

attribute.name: location
attribute.description: Sets the property to the absolute filename of the given file. If the value of this attribute is an absolute path, it is left unchanged (with / and \ characters converted to the current platforms conventions). Otherwise it is taken as a path relative to the project's basedir and expanded.

attribute.name: name
attribute.description: sets the name of the property to set.

attribute.name: prefix
attribute.description: Prefix to apply to properties loaded using file or resource. A "." is appended to the prefix if not specified.

attribute.name: refid
attribute.description: Sets a reference to an Ant datatype declared elsewhere. Only yields reasonable results for references PATH like structures or properties.

attribute.name: resource
attribute.required: one of these, when not using the name attribute
attribute.description: the resource name of a property file to load

attribute.name: value
attribute.required: one of these, when using the name attribute
attribute.description: Sets the value of the property.

element.name: classpath
element.description: The classpath to use when looking up a resource.

task.name: propertyfile
task.description: Modifies settings in a property file.

attribute.name: comment
attribute.description: optional header comment for the file

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: Location of the property file to be edited; required.

task.name: pvcs
task.description:
Extracts the latest edition of the source code from a PVCS repository. PVCS is a version control system developed by Merant.
Before using this tag, the user running ant must have access to the commands of PVCS (get and pcli) and must have access to the repository. Note that the way to specify the repository is platform dependent so use property to specify location of repository.
This version has been tested agains PVCS version 6.5 and 6.6 under Windows and Solaris. 19-04-2001

The task now has a more robust parser. It allows for platform independant file paths and supports file names with (). Thanks to Erik Husby for bringing the bug to my attention. 27-04-2001

UNC paths are now handled properly. Fix provided by Don Jeffery. He also added an UpdateOnly flag that, when true, conditions the PVCS get using the -U option to only update those files that have a modification time (in PVCS) that is newer than the existing workfile.

attribute.name: filenameformat
attribute.description: The format of the folder names. This must be in a format suitable for java.text.MessageFormat. Index 1 of the format will be used as the file name. Defaults to {0}-arc({1})

attribute.name: force
attribute.description: Specifies the value of the force argument. If set to yes all files that exists and are writable are overwritten. Default no causes the files that are writable to be ignored. This stops the PVCS command get to stop asking questions!

attribute.name: ignorereturncode
attribute.description: If set to true the return value from executing the pvcs commands are ignored; default false.

attribute.name: label
attribute.description: Only files marked with this label are extracted.

attribute.name: linestart
attribute.description: What a valid return value from PVCS looks like when it describes a file. Defaults to "P:. If you are not using an UNC name for your repository and the drive letter P is incorrect for your setup, you may need to change this value, UNC names will always be accepted.

attribute.name: promotiongroup
attribute.description: Specifies the name of the promotiongroup argument

attribute.name: pvcsbin
attribute.description: Specifies the location of the PVCS bin directory; optional if on the PATH. On some systems the PVCS executables pcli and get are not found in the PATH. In such cases this attribute should be set to the bin directory of the PVCS installation containing the executables mentioned before. If this attribute isn't specified the tag expects the executables to be found using the PATH environment variable.

attribute.name: pvcsproject
attribute.description: The project within the PVCS repository to extract files from; default "/"

attribute.name: repository
attribute.description: The network name of the PVCS repository; required.

attribute.name: updateonly
attribute.description: If set to true files are fetched only if newer than existing local files; default false.

attribute.name: workspace
attribute.description: Workspace to use. By specifying a workspace, the files are extracted to that location. A PVCS workspace is a name for a location of the workfiles and isn't as such the location itself. You define the location for a workspace using the PVCS GUI clients. If this isn't specified the default workspace for the current user is used.

element.name: pvcsproject
element.description: Specify a project within the PVCS repository to extract files from.

task.name: record
task.description:
Adds a listener to the current build process that records the output to a file.

Several recorders can exist at the same time. Each recorder is associated with a file. The filename is used as a unique identifier for the recorders. The first call to the recorder task with an unused filename will create a recorder (using the parameters provided) and add it to the listeners of the build. All subsequent calls to the recorder task using this filename will modify that recorders state (recording or not) or other properties (like logging level).

Some technical issues: the file's print stream is flushed for "finished" events (buildFinished, targetFinished and taskFinished), and is closed on a buildFinished event.

attribute.name: action
attribute.description: Sets the action for the associated recorder entry.

attribute.name: append
attribute.description: Whether or not the logger should append to a previous file.

attribute.name: loglevel
attribute.description: Sets the level to which this recorder entry should log to.

attribute.name: name
attribute.description: Sets the name of the file to log to, and the name of the recorder entry.

task.name: rename
task.description: Renames a file.

attribute.name: dest
attribute.description: Sets the new name of the file.

attribute.name: replace
attribute.description: Sets whether an existing file should be replaced.

attribute.name: src
attribute.description: Sets the file to be renamed.

attribute.name: fromextension
attribute.description: The string that files must end in to be renamed

attribute.name: replace
attribute.description: store replace attribute - this determines whether the target file should be overwritten if present

attribute.name: srcdir
attribute.description: Set the source dir to find the files to be renamed.

attribute.name: toextension
attribute.description: The string that renamed files will end with on completion

task.name: replace
task.description: Replaces all occurrences of one or more string tokens with given values in the indicated files. Each value can be either a string or the value of a property available in a designated property file. If you want to replace a text that crosses line boundaries, you must use a nested <replacetoken> element.

attribute.name: dir
attribute.description: The base directory to use when replacing a token in multiple files; required if file is not defined.

attribute.name: encoding
attribute.required: no - defaults to default jvm encoding
attribute.description: Set the file encoding to use on the files read and written by the task; defaults to default JVM encoding

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: Set the source file; required unless dir is set.

attribute.name: propertyfile
attribute.required: yes only if property attribute of <replacefilter> is used.
attribute.description: The name of a property file from which properties specified using nested <replacefilter> elements are drawn; Required only if property attribute of <replacefilter> is used.

attribute.name: replacefilterfile
attribute.description: Sets the name of a property file containing filters. Each property will be treated as a replacefilter where token is the name of the property and value is the value of the property.

attribute.name: summary
attribute.required: no, by default no summary is produced
attribute.description: Indicates whether a summary of the replace operation should be produced, detailing how many token occurrences and files were processed; default=false

attribute.name: token
attribute.required: yes, unless a nested replacetoken element or the replacefilterfile attribute is used.
attribute.description: Set the string token to replace; required unless a nested replacetoken element or the replacefilterfile attribute is used.

attribute.name: value
attribute.description: Set the string value to use as token replacement; optional, default is the empty string ""

element.name: replacetoken
element.description: the token to filter as the text of a nested element

element.name: replacevalue
element.description: the string to replace the token as the text of a nested element

element.name: replacefilter
element.description: Add a nested <replacefilter> element.

task.name: replaceregexp
task.description: Performs regular expression string replacements in a text file. The input file(s) must be able to be properly processed by a Reader instance. That is, they must be text only, no binary. The syntax of the regular expression depends on the implemtation that you choose to use. The system property ant.regexp.regexpimpl will be the classname of the implementation that will be used (the default is org.apache.tools.ant.util.regexp.JakartaOroRegexp and requires the Jakarta Oro Package).

attribute.name: byline
attribute.description: Process the file(s) one line at a time, executing the replacement on one line at a time. This is useful if you want to only replace the first occurence of a regular expression on each line, which is not easy to do when processing the file as a whole. Defaults to false.

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: file for which the regular expression should be replaced; required unless a nested fileset is supplied.

attribute.name: flags
attribute.description:
The flags to use when matching the regular expression. For more information, consult the Perl5 syntax.
  • g : Global replacement. Replace all occurences found
  • i : Case Insensitive. Do not consider case in the match
  • m : Multiline. Treat the string as multiple lines of input, using "^" and "$" as the start or end of any line, respectively, rather than start or end of string.
  • s : Singleline. Treat the string as a single line of input, using "." to match any character, including a newline, which normally, it would not match.

attribute.name: match
attribute.description: the regular expression pattern to match in the file(s); required if no nested <regexp> is used

attribute.name: replace
attribute.description: The substitution pattern to place in the file(s) in place of the regular expression. Required if no nested <substitution> is used

element.name: fileset
element.description: list files to apply the replacement to

element.name: regexp
element.description: A regular expression. You can use this element to refer to a previously defined regular expression datatype instance

element.name: substitution
element.description: A substitution pattern. You can use this element to refer to a previously defined substitution pattern datatype instance.

task.name: rmic
task.description:
Runs the rmic compiler against classes.

Rmic can be run on a single class (as specified with the classname attribute) or a number of classes at once (all classes below base that are neither _Stub nor _Skel classes). If you want to rmic a single class and this class is a class nested into another class, you have to specify the classname in the form Outer$$Inner instead of Outer.Inner.

attribute.name: base
attribute.description: Sets the location to store the compiled files.

attribute.name: classname
attribute.description: Sets the the class to run rmic against

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Set the classpath to be used for this compilation.

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: Adds to the classpath a reference to a <path> defined elsewhere.

attribute.name: compiler
debug
attribute.description: Generate debug info (passes -g to rmic); defaults to false

attribute.name: extdirs
attribute.description: Sets the extension directories that will be used during the compilation.

attribute.name: filtering
attribute.description: indicates whether token filtering should take place; default=false

attribute.name: idl
attribute.description: Indicates that IDL output should be generated. This defaults to false if not set.

attribute.name: idlopts
attribute.description: pass additional arguments for idl compile

attribute.name: iiop
attribute.description: Indicates that IIOP compatible stubs should be generated; defaults to false if not set.

attribute.name: iiopopts
attribute.description: Set additional arguments for iiop.

attribute.name: includeantruntime
attribute.description: Sets whether or not to include ant's own classpath in this task's classpath. Default is true.

attribute.name: includejavaruntime
attribute.description: Whether to include the default run-time libraries from the executing VM; defaults to no.

attribute.name: sourcebase
attribute.description: Optional directory to save generated source files to.

attribute.name: stubversion
attribute.description: Specify the JDK version for the generated stub code. Specify "1.1" to pass the "-v1.1" option to rmic.

attribute.name: verify
attribute.description: Flag to enable verification so that the classes found by the directory match are checked to see if they implement java.rmi.Remote. Defaults to false if not set.

element.name: classpath
element.description: Creates a nested classpath element.

element.name: compilerarg
element.description: Adds an implementation specific command line argument.

element.name: extdirs
element.description: Maybe creates a nested extdirs element.

task.name: rpm
task.description: Invokes the rpm tool to build a Linux installation file.

attribute.name: cleanbuilddir
attribute.description: Flag (default=false) to remove the generated files in the BUILD directory

attribute.name: command
attribute.description: What command to issue to the rpm tool. The default is "-bb".

attribute.name: error
attribute.description: Optional file to save stderr to

attribute.name: output
attribute.description: Optional file to save stdout to.

attribute.name: removesource
attribute.description: Flag (default=false) to remove the sources after the build. See the the <tt>--rmsource</tt> option of rpmbuild.

attribute.name: removespec
attribute.description: Flag (default=false) to remove the spec file from SPECS

attribute.name: specfile
attribute.description: The name of the spec File to use; required.

attribute.name: topdir
attribute.description: The directory which will have the expected subdirectories, SPECS, SOURCES, BUILD, SRPMS. If this isn't specified, the <tt>baseDir</tt> value is used

task.name: script
task.description: Executes a script.

attribute.name: language
attribute.description: Defines the language (required).

attribute.name: src
attribute.description: Load the script from an external file.

task.name: sequential
task.description:
Sequential is a container task - it can contain other Ant tasks. The nested tasks are simply executed in sequence. Sequential's primary use is to support the sequential execution of a subset of tasks within the {@link Parallel Parallel Task}

The sequential task has no attributes and does not support any nested elements apart from Ant tasks. Any valid Ant task may be embedded within the sequential task.

task.name: serverdeploy
task.description: Controls hot deployment tools for J2EE servers. This class is used as a framework for the creation of vendor specific hot deployment tools.

attribute.name: action
attribute.description: The action to be performed, usually "deploy"; required. Some tools support additional actions, such as "delete", "list", "undeploy", "update"...

attribute.name: source
attribute.description: The filename of the component to be deployed; optional depending upon the tool and the action.

element.name: generic
element.description:
Creates a generic deployment tool.

Ant calls this method on creation to handle embedded "generic" elements in the ServerDeploy task.

element.name: jonas
element.description:
Creates a JOnAS deployment tool, for deployment to JOnAS servers.

Ant calls this method on creation to handle embedded "jonas" elements in the ServerDeploy task.

element.name: weblogic
element.description:
Creates a WebLogic deployment tool, for deployment to WebLogic servers.

Ant calls this method on creation to handle embedded "weblogic" elements in the ServerDeploy task.

task.name: setproxy
task.description: Sets Java's web proxy properties, so that tasks and code run in the same JVM can have through-the-firewall access to remote web sites, and remote ftp sites. You can nominate an http and ftp proxy, or a socks server, reset the server settings, or do nothing at all.

attribute.name: nonproxyhosts
attribute.description: A list of hosts to bypass the proxy on. These should be separated with the vertical bar character '|'. Only in Java 1.4 does ftp use this list. e.g. fozbot.corp.sun.com|*.eng.sun.com

attribute.name: proxyhost
attribute.description: the HTTP/ftp proxy host. Set this to "" for the http proxy option to be disabled

attribute.name: proxyport
attribute.description: the HTTP/ftp proxy port number; default is 80

attribute.name: socksproxyhost
attribute.description: The name of a Socks server. Set to "" to turn socks proxying off.

attribute.name: socksproxyport
attribute.description: Set the ProxyPort for socks connections. The default value is 1080

task.name: signjar
task.description:
Signs jar or zip files with the javasign command line tool. The tool's detailed dependency checking: files are only signed if they are not signed. The signedjar attribute can point to the file to generate; if this file exists then its modification date is used as a cue as to whether to resign any JAR file.
Note: Requires Java 1.2 or later.

attribute.name: alias
attribute.description: the alias to sign under; required

attribute.name: internalsf
attribute.description: Flag to include the .SF file inside the signature; default false

attribute.name: jar
attribute.description: The jar file to sign.

attribute.name: keypass
attribute.description: Password for private key (if different).

attribute.name: keystore
attribute.description: Keystore location.

attribute.name: sectionsonly
attribute.description: Flag to compute hash of entire manifest; default false

attribute.name: sigfile
attribute.description: Name of .SF/.DSA file.

attribute.name: signedjar
attribute.description: name of signed JAR file; optional

attribute.name: storepass
attribute.description: password for keystore integrity; required

attribute.name: storetype
attribute.description: keystore type; optional

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description: Enable verbose output when signing ; optional: default false

element.name: fileset
element.description: Adds a set of files to sign

task.name: sleep
task.description:
Sleep, or pause, for a period of time. A task for sleeping a short period of time, useful when a build or deployment process requires an interval between tasks.

A negative value can be supplied to any of attributes provided the total sleep time is positive, pending fundamental changes in physics and JVM execution tims

Note that sleep times are always hints to be interpred by the OS how it feels small times may either be ignored or rounded up to a minimum timeslice. Note also that the system clocks often have a fairly low granularity too, which complicates measuring how long a sleep actually took.

attribute.name: failonerror
attribute.description: flag controlling whether to break the build on an error.

attribute.name: hours
attribute.description: hours to add to the sleep time.

attribute.name: milliseconds
attribute.description: milliseconds to add to the sleep time

attribute.name: minutes
attribute.description: minutes to add to the sleep time

attribute.name: seconds
attribute.description: seconds to add to the sleep time

task.name: soscheckin
task.description: Commits and unlocks files in Visual SourceSafe via a SourceOffSite server.

attribute.name: comment
attribute.description: Set the comment to apply to all files being labelled; optional, only valid in SOSLabel

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: Set the Filename to act upon; optional. If no file is specified then the tasks act upon the project

attribute.name: label
attribute.description: Set the labeled version to operate on in SourceSafe

attribute.name: localpath
attribute.description: Override the working directory and get to the specified path; optional.

attribute.name: nocache
attribute.description: flag to disable the cache when set; optional needed if SOSHOME is set as an environment variable.

attribute.name: nocompress
attribute.description: Flag that disables compression when set; optional, default

attribute.name: password
attribute.description: Set the SourceSafe password; optional.

attribute.name: projectpath
attribute.description: Set the SourceSafe project path without the "$" prefix; required

attribute.name: recursive
attribute.description: Flag to recursively apply the action (not valid on all SOS tasks ); optional, default false

attribute.name: soscmd
attribute.description: Set the directory where soscmd(.exe) is located; optional, soscmd must be on the path if omitted.

attribute.name: soshome
attribute.description: The path to the SourceOffSite home directory

attribute.name: sosserverpath
attribute.description: Set the address and port of SourceOffSite Server, eg. 192.168.0.1:8888 ; required.

attribute.name: username
attribute.description: Set the SourceSafe username; required.

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description: Enable verbose output; optional, default false

attribute.name: version
attribute.description: Set the a version number to get - only works with the SOSGet on a file; optional.

attribute.name: vssserverpath
attribute.description: Set the path to the location of the ss.ini file; required.

task.name: sound
task.description: Plays a sound file at the end of the build, according to whether the build failed or succeeded. There are three attributes to be set: source: the location of the audio file to be played duration: play the sound file continuously until "duration" milliseconds has expired loops: the number of times the sound file should be played until stopped I have only tested this with .WAV and .AIFF sound file formats. Both seem to work fine. plans for the future: - use the midi api to define sounds (or drum beat etc) in xml and have Ant play them back

element.name: fail
element.description: add a sound when the build fails

element.name: success
element.description: add a sound when the build succeeds

task.name: splash
task.description: Creates a splash screen. The splash screen is displayed for the duration of the build and includes a handy progress bar as well. Use in conjunction with the sound task to provide interest whilst waiting for your builds to complete...

attribute.name: imageurl
attribute.description: A URL pointing to an image to display; optional, default antlogo.gif from the classpath.

attribute.name: password
attribute.description: Proxy password; required if <tt>user</tt> is set.

attribute.name: port
attribute.description: Proxy port; optional, default 80.

attribute.name: proxy
attribute.description: name of proxy; optional.

attribute.name: showduration
attribute.description: how long to show the splash screen in milliseconds, optional; default 5000 ms.

attribute.name: user
attribute.description: Proxy user; optional, default =none.

task.name: sql
task.description:
Executes a series of SQL statements on a database using JDBC.

Statements can either be read in from a text file using the src attribute or from between the enclosing SQL tags.

Multiple statements can be provided, separated by semicolons (or the defined delimiter). Individual lines within the statements can be commented using either --, // or REM at the start of the line.

The autocommit attribute specifies whether auto-commit should be turned on or off whilst executing the statements. If auto-commit is turned on each statement will be executed and committed. If it is turned off the statements will all be executed as one transaction.

The onerror attribute specifies how to proceed when an error occurs during the execution of one of the statements. The possible values are: continue execution, only show the error; stop execution and commit transaction; and abort execution and transaction and fail task.

attribute.name: append
attribute.description: whether output should be appended to or overwrite an existing file. Defaults to false.

attribute.name: autocommit
attribute.description: Auto commit flag for database connection; optional, default false.

attribute.name: caching
attribute.description: Caching loaders / driver. This is to avoid getting an OutOfMemoryError when calling this task multiple times in a row; default: true

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Sets the classpath for loading the driver.

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: Set the classpath for loading the driver using the classpath reference.

attribute.name: delimitertype
attribute.description:
Set the delimiter type: "normal" or "row" (default "normal").

The delimiter type takes two values - normal and row. Normal means that any occurence of the delimiter terminate the SQL command whereas with row, only a line containing just the delimiter is recognized as the end of the command.

attribute.name: driver
attribute.description: Class name of the JDBC driver; required.

attribute.name: encoding
attribute.required: no - defaults to default jvm encoding
attribute.description: Set the file encoding to use on the SQL files read in

attribute.name: onerror
attribute.description: Action to perform when statement fails: continue, stop, or abort optional; default "abort"

attribute.name: output
attribute.description: Set the output file; optional, defaults to the Ant log.

attribute.name: password
attribute.description: Sets the password; required.

attribute.name: print
attribute.description: Print result sets from the statements; optional, default false

attribute.name: rdbms
attribute.description: Execute task only if the lower case product name of the DB matches this

attribute.name: showheaders
attribute.description: Print headers for result sets from the statements; optional, default true.

attribute.name: src
attribute.required: yes, unless statements enclosed within tags
attribute.description: Set the name of the SQL file to be run. Required unless statements are enclosed in the buildfile

attribute.name: url
attribute.description: Sets the database connection URL; required.

attribute.name: userid
attribute.description: Set the user name for the connection; required.

attribute.name: version
attribute.description: Sets the version string, execute task only if rdbms version match; optional.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Adds a set of files (nested fileset attribute).

element.name: classpath
element.description: Add a path to the classpath for loading the driver.

element.name: transaction
element.description: Add a SQL transaction to execute

body.description: Set an inline SQL command to execute. NB: Properties are not expanded in this text.

task.name: stylebook
task.description:
Executes the Apache Stylebook documentation generator. Unlike the commandline version of this tool, all three arguments are required to run stylebook.

Being extended from <Java>, all the parent's attributes and options are available. Do not set any apart from the classpath as they are not guaranteed to be there in future.

attribute.name: append
attribute.description: If true, append output to existing file.

attribute.name: book
attribute.description: The book xml file that the documentation generation starts from; required.

attribute.name: classname
attribute.description: Sets the Java class to execute.

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Set the classpath to be used when running the Java class

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: Classpath to use, by reference.

attribute.name: dir
attribute.description: The working directory of the process

attribute.name: failonerror
attribute.description: If true, then fail if the command exits with a returncode other than 0

attribute.name: fork
attribute.description: If true, execute in a new VM.

attribute.name: jvmversion
attribute.description: Sets the JVM version.

attribute.name: jar
attribute.description: The location of the JAR file to execute.

attribute.name: jvm
attribute.description: Set the command used to start the VM (only if not forking).

attribute.name: jvmargs
attribute.description: Set the command line arguments for the JVM.

attribute.name: loaderconfig
attribute.description: A loader configuration to send to stylebook; optional.

attribute.name: maxmemory
attribute.description: Corresponds to -mx or -Xmx depending on VM version.

attribute.name: newenvironment
attribute.description:
If true, use a completely new environment.

Will be ignored if we are not forking a new VM.

attribute.name: output
attribute.description: File the output of the process is redirected to.

attribute.name: skindirectory
attribute.description: the directory that contains the stylebook skin; required.

attribute.name: targetdirectory
attribute.description: the destination directory where the documentation is generated; required.

attribute.name: timeout
attribute.description: Timeout in milliseconds after which the process will be killed.

element.name: env
element.description:
Adds an environment variable.

Will be ignored if we are not forking a new VM.

element.name: sysproperty
element.description: Adds a system property.

element.name: arg
element.description: Adds a command-line argument.

element.name: classpath
element.description: Adds a path to the classpath.

element.name: jvmarg
element.description: Adds a JVM argument.

task.name: tar
task.description: Creates a tar archive.

attribute.name: basedir
attribute.description: This is the base directory to look in for things to tar.

attribute.name: compression
attribute.description:
Set compression method. Allowable values are
  • none - no compression
  • gzip - Gzip compression
  • bzip2 - Bzip2 compression

attribute.name: destfile
attribute.description: Set is the name/location of where to create the tar file.

attribute.name: longfile
attribute.description:
Set how to handle long files, those with a path>100 chars. Optional, default=warn.

Allowable values are

  • truncate - paths are truncated to the maximum length
  • fail - paths greater than the maximim cause a build exception
  • warn - paths greater than the maximum cause a warning and GNU is used
  • gnu - GNU extensions are used for any paths greater than the maximum.
  • omit - paths greater than the maximum are omitted from the archive

element.name: tarfileset
element.description: Add a new fileset with the option to specify permissions

task.name: taskdef
task.description:
Adds a task definition to the current project, such that this new task can be used in the current project. Two attributes are needed, the name that identifies this task uniquely, and the full name of the class (including the packages) that implements this task.

You can also define a group of tasks at once using the file or resource attributes. These attributes point to files in the format of Java property files. Each line defines a single task in the format:

 taskname=fully.qualified.java.classname

attribute.name: classname
attribute.required: yes, unless file or resource have been specified.
attribute.description: the full class name of the object being defined. Required, unless file or resource have been specified.

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Set the classpath to be used when searching for component being defined

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: reference to a classpath to use when loading the files. To actually share the same loader, set loaderref as well

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: Name of the property file to load ant name/classname pairs from.

attribute.name: loaderref
attribute.description: Use the reference to locate the loader. If the loader is not found, taskdef will use the specified classpath and register it with the specified name. This allow multiple taskdef/typedef to use the same class loader, so they can be used together. It eliminate the need to put them in the CLASSPATH.

attribute.name: name
attribute.required: yes, unless file or resource have been specified.
attribute.description: The name of the data type.

attribute.name: resource
attribute.description: Name of the property resource to load ant name/classname pairs from.

element.name: classpath
element.description: Create the classpath to be used when searching for component being defined

task.name: telnet
task.description: Automates the telnet protocol.

attribute.name: initialcr
attribute.description: send a carriage return after connecting; optional, defaults to false.

attribute.name: password
attribute.description: Set the the login password to use required if <tt>userid</tt> is set.

attribute.name: port
attribute.description: Set the tcp port to connect to; default is 23.

attribute.name: server
attribute.description: Set the hostname or address of the remote server.

attribute.name: timeout
attribute.description: set a default timeout in seconds to wait for a response, zero means forever (the default)

attribute.name: userid
attribute.description: Set the the login id to use on the server; required if <tt>password</tt> is set.

element.name: read
element.description: A string to wait for from the server. A subTask <read> tag was found. Create the object, Save it in our list, and return it.

element.name: write
element.description: Add text to send to the server A subTask <write> tag was found. Create the object, Save it in our list, and return it.

task.name: tempfile
task.description:
This task sets a property to the name of a temporary file. Unlike the Java1.2 method to create a temporary file, this task does work on Java1.1. Also, it does not actually create the temporary file, but it does guarantee that the file did not exist when the task was executed.

Examples 

<tempfile property="temp.file" />
create a temporary file 
<tempfile property="temp.file" suffix=".xml" />
create a temporary file with the .xml suffix. 
<tempfile property="temp.file" destDir="build"/>
create a temp file in the build subdir

attribute.name: destdir
attribute.description: destination directory. If null, the parent directory is used instead

attribute.name: prefix
attribute.description: optional prefix string

attribute.name: property
attribute.description: The property you wish to assign the temporary file to

attribute.name: suffix
attribute.description: Suffix string for the temp file (optional)

task.name: touch
task.description:
Touch a file and/or fileset(s); corresponds to the Unix touch command.

If the file to touch doesn't exist, an empty one is created.

Note: Setting the modification time of files is not supported in JDK 1.1.

attribute.name: datetime
file
attribute.required: unless a nested fileset element has been specified.
attribute.description: Sets a single source file to touch. If the file does not exist an empty file will be created.

attribute.name: millis
attribute.description: the new modification time of the file in milliseconds since midnight Jan 1 1970. Optional, default=now

element.name: fileset
element.description: Add a set of files to touch

task.name: translate
task.description: Translates text embedded in files using Resource Bundle files.

attribute.name: bundle
attribute.description: Sets Family name of resource bundle; required.

attribute.name: bundlecountry
attribute.description: Sets locale specific country of resource bundle; optional.

attribute.name: bundleencoding
attribute.description: Sets Resource Bundle file encoding scheme; optional. Defaults to source file encoding

attribute.name: bundlelanguage
attribute.description: Sets locale specific language of resource bundle; optional.

attribute.name: bundlevariant
attribute.description: Sets locale specific variant of resource bundle; optional.

attribute.name: destencoding
attribute.description: Sets destination file encoding scheme; optional. Defaults to source file encoding

attribute.name: endtoken
attribute.description: Sets ending token to identify keys; required.

attributes.attribute:
whether it is newer than the source file as well as the
Whether or not to overwrite existing file irrespective of whether it is newer than the source file as well as the resource bundle file. Defaults to false.

attribute.name: srcencoding
attribute.description: Sets source file encoding scheme; optional, defaults to encoding of local system.

attribute.name: starttoken
attribute.description: Sets starting token to identify keys; required.

attribute.name: todir
attribute.description: Sets Destination directory; required.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Adds a set of files to translate as a nested fileset element.

task.name: tstamp
task.description: Sets properties to the current time, or offsets from the current time. The default properties are TSTAMP, DSTAMP and TODAY;

attribute.name: prefix
attribute.description: Set a prefix for the properties. If the prefix does not end with a "." one is automatically added

element.name: format
element.description: create a custom format with the the current prefix.

task.name: typedef
task.description:
Adds a data type definition to the current project. Two attributes are needed, the name that identifies this data type uniquely, and the full name of the class (including the packages) that implements this type.

You can also define a group of data types at once using the file or resource attributes. These attributes point to files in the format of Java property files. Each line defines a single data type in the format:

 typename=fully.qualified.java.classname

Typedef should be used to add your own types to the system. Data types are things likepaths or filesets that can be defined at the project level and referenced via their ID attribute.

Custom data types usually need custom tasks to put them to good use.

attribute.name: classname
attribute.required: yes, unless file or resource have been specified.
attribute.description: the full class name of the object being defined. Required, unless file or resource have been specified.

attribute.name: classpath
attribute.description: Set the classpath to be used when searching for component being defined

attribute.name: classpathref
attribute.description: reference to a classpath to use when loading the files. To actually share the same loader, set loaderref as well

attribute.name: file
attribute.description: Name of the property file to load ant name/classname pairs from.

attribute.name: loaderref
attribute.description: Use the reference to locate the loader. If the loader is not found, taskdef will use the specified classpath and register it with the specified name. This allow multiple taskdef/typedef to use the same class loader, so they can be used together. It eliminate the need to put them in the CLASSPATH.

attribute.name: name
attribute.required: yes, unless file or resource have been specified.
attribute.description: Name of the property resource to load ant name/classname pairs from.

attribute.name: resource
attribute.description: Name of the property resource to load ant name/classname pairs from.

element.name: classpath
element.description: Create the classpath to be used when searching for component being defined

task.name: untar
task.description:
Untar a file.

For JDK 1.1 "last modified time" field is set to current time instead of being carried from the archive file.

PatternSets are used to select files to extract from the archive. If no patternset is used, all files are extracted.

FileSet>s may be used used to select archived files to perform unarchival upon.

File permissions will not be restored on extracted files.

The untar task recognizes the long pathname entries used by GNU tar.

attribute.name: compression
attribute.description:
Set decompression algorithm to use; default=none. Allowable values are
  • none - no compression
  • gzip - Gzip compression
  • bzip2 - Bzip2 compression

attribute.name: dest
attribute.description: Set the destination directory. File will be unzipped into the destination directory.

attribute.name: overwrite
attribute.description: Should we overwrite files in dest, even if they are newer than the corresponding entries in the archive?

attribute.name: src
attribute.description: Set the path to zip-file.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Add a fileset

element.name: patternset
element.description: Add a patternset

task.name: unzip
task.description: Unzip a file.

attribute.name: dest
attribute.description: Set the destination directory. File will be unzipped into the destination directory.

attribute.name: overwrite
attribute.description: Should we overwrite files in dest, even if they are newer than the corresponding entries in the archive?

attribute.name: src
attribute.required: yes, if filesets are not used.
attribute.description: Set the path to zip-file.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Add a fileset

element.name: patternset
element.description: Add a patternset

task.name: uptodate
task.description: Sets the given property if the specified target has a timestamp greater than all of the source files.

attribute.name: property
attribute.description: The property to set if the target file is more up-to-date than (each of) the source file(s).

attribute.name: srcfile
attribute.required: yes, unless a nested <srcfiles> element is present.
attribute.description: The file that must be older than the target file if the property is to be set.

attribute.name: targetfile
attribute.required: yes, unless a nested <mapper> element is present.
attribute.description: The file which must be more up-to-date than (each of) the source file(s) if the property is to be set.

attribute.name: value
attribute.description: The value to set the named property to if the target file is more up-to-date than (each of) the source file(s). Defaults to 'true'.

element.name: srcfiles
element.description: Nested <srcfiles> element.

element.name: mapper
element.description: Defines the FileNameMapper to use (nested mapper element).

task.name: vajexport
task.description: Exports Java source files, class files and/or resources from the Visual Age for Java workspace to the file system. Exports can be specified by giving the VAJ project name and package name(s). This works very similar to FileSets.

attribute.name: defaultexcludes
attribute.description: Sets whether default exclusions should be used or not; default true.

attribute.name: destdir
attribute.description: Set the destination directory into which the selected items should be exported; required.

attribute.name: excludes
attribute.description: Sets the set of exclude patterns. Patterns may be separated by a comma or a space. Currently only patterns denoting packages are supported

attribute.name: exportclasses
attribute.description: optional flag to export the class files; default false.

attribute.name: exportdebuginfo
attribute.description: optional flag to export the debug info; default false. debug info

attribute.name: exportresources
attribute.description: optional flag to export the resource file; default true.

attribute.name: exportsources
attribute.description: optional flag to export the Java files; default true.

attribute.name: includes
attribute.description: Sets the set of include patterns. Patterns may be separated by a comma or a space. Currently only patterns denoting packages are supported.

attribute.name: overwrite
attribute.description: if Overwrite is set, files will be overwritten during export

attribute.name: remote
attribute.description: Name and port of a remote tool server, optional. Format: <servername>:<port no>. If this attribute is set, the tasks will be executed on the specified tool server.

element.name: exclude
element.description: add a name entry on the exclude list

element.name: include
element.description: add a name entry on the include list

task.name: vajimport
task.description: Import source, class files, and resources to the Visual Age for Java workspace.

attribute.name: defaultexcludes
attribute.description: Sets whether default exclusions should be used or not.

attribute.name: importclasses
attribute.description: Flag to import .class files; optional, default false.

attribute.name: importresources
attribute.description: Import resource files (anything that doesn't end in .class or .java); optional, default true.

attribute.name: importsources
attribute.description: Import .java files; optional, default true.

attribute.name: project
attribute.description: The VisualAge for Java Project name to import into.

attribute.name: remote
attribute.description: Name and port of a remote tool server, optiona. Format: <servername>:<port no>. If this attribute is set, the tasks will be executed on the specified tool server.

element.name: fileset
element.description: Adds a set of files (nested fileset attribute).

task.name: vajload
task.description:
Load specific project versions into the Visual Age for Java workspace. Each project and version name has to be specified completely. Example:
<vajload>  <project name="MyVAProject" version="2.1"/>  <project name="Apache Xerces" version="1.2.0"/> </vajload>

attribute.name: remote
attribute.description: Name and port of a remote tool server, optiona. Format: <servername>:<port no>. If this attribute is set, the tasks will be executed on the specified tool server.

element.name: vajproject
element.description: Add a project description entry on the project list.

task.name: vssadd
task.description: Performs Add commands to Microsoft Visual SourceSafe. Based on the VSS Checkin code by Martin Poeschl

attribute.name: autoresponse
attribute.description: What to respond with (sets the -I option). By default, -I- is used; values of Y or N will be appended to this.

attribute.name: comment
attribute.description:
Sets the comment to apply; optional.

If this is null or empty, it will be replaced with "-" which is what SourceSafe uses for an empty comment.

attribute.name: localpath
attribute.description: Set the local path.

attribute.name: login
attribute.description:
The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

attribute.name: recursive
attribute.description: Set behaviour recursive or non-recursive

attribute.name: serverpath
attribute.description: Set the directory where srssafe.ini resides; optional.

attribute.name: ssdir
attribute.description: directory where ss.exe resides; optional. By default the task expects it to be in the PATH.

attribute.name: vsspath
attribute.description:
SourceSafe path which specifies the project/file(s) you wish to perform the action on; required. You should not specify the leading dollar-sign - it is prepended by Ant automatically.

Ant can't cope with a '$' sign in an attribute so we have to add it here. Also we strip off any 'vss://' prefix which is an XMS special and should probably be removed!

attribute.name: writable
attribute.description: Leave added files writable? Default: false.

Performs CP (Change Project) commands to Microsoft Visual SourceSafe.

This task is typically used before a VssAdd in order to set the target project

Based on the VSS Checkin code by Martin Poeschl

attribute.description: What to respond with (sets the -I option). By default, -I- is used; values of Y or N will be appended to this.

attribute.name: login

The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

If this is null or empty, it will be replaced with "-" which is what SourceSafe uses for an empty comment.

attribute.name: login
attribute.description:
The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

Ant can't cope with a '$' sign in an attribute so we have to add it here. Also we strip off any 'vss://' prefix which is an XMS special and should probably be removed!

task.name: vssget
task.description:
Perform Get commands to Microsoft Visual SourceSafe.

Note that only one of version, date or label should be specified

attribute.name: autoresponse
attribute.description: What to respond with (sets the -I option). By default, -I- is used; values of Y or N will be appended to this.

attributes.attribute:
optional, only one of version, label, or date Set the date to get; optional, only one of version, label, or date allowed.

ORIGINAL COMMENT THAT DOES NOT SEEM AT ALL VALID: Note we assume that if the supplied string has the value "null" that something went wrong and that the string value got populated from a null object. This happens if a ant variable is used e.g. date="${date}" when date has not been defined to ant!

optional, only one of version, label, or date Set the label to get; optional, only one of version, label, or date allowed.

Note we assume that if the supplied string has the value "null" that something went wrong and that the string value got populated from a null object. This happens if a ant variable is used e.g. label="${label_server}" when label_server has not been defined to ant!

attribute.name: localpath
attribute.description: Override the working directory and get to the specified path; optional.

attribute.name: login
attribute.description:
The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

attribute.name: quiet
attribute.description: Flag to suppress output when true ; false by default.

attribute.name: recursive
attribute.description: Flag to tell the task to recurse down the tree; optional, default false.

attribute.name: serverpath
attribute.description: Set the directory where srssafe.ini resides; optional.

attribute.name: ssdir
attribute.description: directory where ss.exe resides; optional. By default the task expects it to be in the PATH.

attributes.attribute:
optional, only one of version, label, or date Set a version number to get; optional, only one of version, label, or date allowed.

ORIGINAL COMMENT THAT DOES NOT SEEM AT ALL VALID: Note we assume that if the supplied string has the value "null" that something went wrong and that the string value got populated from a null object. This happens if a ant variable is used e.g. version="${ver_server}" when ver_server has not been defined to ant! NO, in this case the version string is "${ver_server}".

attribute.name: vsspath
attribute.description:
SourceSafe path which specifies the project/file(s) you wish to perform the action on; required. You should not specify the leading dollar-sign - it is prepended by Ant automatically.

Ant can't cope with a '$' sign in an attribute so we have to add it here. Also we strip off any 'vss://' prefix which is an XMS special and should probably be removed!

attribute.name: writable
attribute.description: make fetched files writable; optional, default false.

task.name: vsshistory
task.description: Performs History commands to Microsoft Visual SourceSafe.

attribute.name: dateformat
attribute.description: Format of dates in fromDate and toDate; optional. Used when calculating dates with the numdays attribute. This string uses the formatting rules of SimpleDateFormat. Defaults to DateFormat.SHORT.

attribute.name: fromdate
attribute.description: Set the Start Date for the Comparison of two versions; optional.

attribute.name: fromlabel
attribute.description: Set the Start Label; optional

attribute.name: login
attribute.description:
The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

attribute.name: numdays
attribute.description:
Set the number of days for comparison; optional.

The default value is 2 days. (maybe)

attribute.name: output
attribute.description: Set the output file name for the history; optional.

attribute.name: recursive
attribute.description: Flag to tell the task to recurse down the tree; optional, default false.

attribute.name: serverpath
attribute.description: Set the directory where srssafe.ini resides; optional.

attribute.name: ssdir
attribute.description: directory where ss.exe resides; optional. By default the task expects it to be in the PATH.

attribute.name: style
attribute.description: Specify the output style; optional.

attribute.name: todate
attribute.description: Set the End Date for the Comparison of two versions; optional.

attribute.name: tolabel
attribute.description: Set the End Label ; optional

attribute.name: user
attribute.description: Name the user whose changes we would like to see; optional

attribute.name: vsspath
attribute.description:
SourceSafe path which specifies the project/file(s) you wish to perform the action on; required. You should not specify the leading dollar-sign - it is prepended by Ant automatically.

Ant can't cope with a '$' sign in an attribute so we have to add it here. Also we strip off any 'vss://' prefix which is an XMS special and should probably be removed!

task.name: vsslabel
task.description: Performs Label commands to Microsoft Visual SourceSafe.

attribute.name: autoresponse
attribute.description: What to respond with (sets the -I option). By default, -I- is used; values of Y or N will be appended to this.

attribute.name: comment
attribute.description:
The comment to use for this label; optional. Empty or '-' for no comment.

If this is null or empty, it will be replaced with "-" which is what SourceSafe uses for an empty comment.

attribute.name: label
attribute.description:
Set the label to apply; required.

Note we assume that if the supplied string has the value "null" that something went wrong and that the string value got populated from a null object. This happens if a ant variable is used e.g. label="${label_server}" when label_server has not been defined to ant!

attribute.name: login
attribute.description:
The login to use when accessing VSS, formatted as "username,password"; optional.

You can omit the password if your database is not password protected. if you have a password and omit it, Ant/VSS will hang.

attribute.name: serverpath
attribute.description: Set the directory where srssafe.ini resides; optional.

attribute.name: ssdir
attribute.description: directory where ss.exe resides; optional. By default the task expects it to be in the PATH.

attribute.name: version
attribute.description:
Name an existing file or project version to label; optional. By default the current version is labelled.

Note we assume that if the supplied string has the value "null" that something went wrong and that the string value got populated from a null object. This happens if a ant variable is used e.g. version="${ver_server}" when ver_server has not been defined to ant!

attribute.name: vsspath
attribute.description:
SourceSafe path which specifies the project/file(s) you wish to perform the action on; required. You should not specify the leading dollar-sign - it is prepended by Ant automatically.

Ant can't cope with a '$' sign in an attribute so we have to add it here. Also we strip off any 'vss://' prefix which is an XMS special and should probably be removed!

task.name: waitfor
task.description: Wait for an external event to occur. Wait for an external process to start or to complete some task. This is useful with the parallel task to syncronize the execution of tests with server startup. The maxwaitunit and checkeveryunit are allowed to have the following values: millesond, second, minute, hour, day and week. The default is millisecond.

attribute.name: checkevery
attribute.description: Set the time between each check

attribute.name: checkeveryunit
attribute.description: Set the check every time unit

attribute.name: maxwait
attribute.description: Set the maximum length of time to wait

attribute.name: maxwaitunit
attribute.description: Set the max wait time unit

attribute.name: timeoutproperty
attribute.description: Name the property to set after a timeout.
